BIG LAW寿命很长。有关说明，请参阅詹姆斯·斯图尔特 (James Stewart) 所著的《合伙人：美国最强大的律师事务所内部》，该书于四十年前出版。除了少数例外，本书的主角公司仍然保持着良好的健康状况。 Cravath、Swaine & Moore、Sullivan & Cromwell 和 Kirkland & Ellis 仍然是华尔街最繁忙的豪华轿车追逐者之一。不太幸运的公司不是破产了，而是失败了。其中一家商店 Donovan, Leisure, Newton & Irvine 于 1998 年关闭。另一家商店 Shearman & Sterling 宣布与英国竞争对手合并。

斯图尔特先生的书中只给了瓦赫特尔、利普顿、罗森和卡茨一个跑龙套的角色。同样的遗漏在今天是不可想象的。 Wachtell 于 1965 年由纽约大学毕业生创立，是美国杰出的董事会顾问。今年上半年，老板们聘请该公司为价值 1000 亿美元的交易提供咨询，并为此付出了高昂的代价。据行业杂志《美国律师》报道，去年 Wachtell 的合伙人每人赚取了 730 万美元，仅略高于柯克兰与埃利斯律师事务所（Kirkland & Ellis），这是一家芝加哥公司，专门为私募股权交易提供咨询服务。以每位律师的利润来衡量，Wachtell 及其交易撮合者（其每位高级员工（“合伙人”）的初级员工（“合伙人”）较少）看起来的生产力几乎是第二名律师事务所的两倍。

超额利润并不是 Wachtell 唯一不寻常的事情。当竞争对手在海外开设商店时，沃赫特尔却只是想在伦敦设立一家前哨基地。盈利排名第二的五家律师事务所平均有 1,700 名律师在 16 个办事处工作； Wachtell 在曼哈顿的一个屋檐下拥有不到 300 名员工。没有正式的合伙协议。合伙人的薪酬按照资历而不是个人贡献“同步”进行。精英主义受到重视。哈佛商学院的案例研究讲述了该公司的指导原则。 “该公司不是一家企业，”一位人士写道。

这种结构反映了瓦赫特尔的专长：为美国老板就押注公司的交易提供建议。该公司在 20 世纪 80 年代建立了声誉，从那时起，Wachtell 的客户就发现了很多值得担心的事情。他们经常给 Wachtell 的创始合伙人之一马丁·利普顿 (Martin Lipton) 打电话。利普顿最著名的纸面发明是股东权利计划，这是一种通过威胁发行大量新股来防御敌意收购的方式。众所周知，“毒丸”在董事会中大受欢迎，以至于到 1986 年，大约三分之一的财富500 强公司都采用了它。 2000 年代，当激进股东成为董事会新的祸害时，老板们找到了利普顿先生作为直言不讳的捍卫者。企业掠夺者基本上已经失去了牙齿，激进主义也不再像十年前那样，但他的影响力仍然存在。利普顿先生还帮助开创了“利益相关者资本主义”的概念，该概念依赖于政治家首席执行官识别和关注股东以外的利益。这个想法在 2019 年被商业领袖会议商业圆桌会议采纳。

一些人认为这些创新是帝国老板的盾牌，而不是遏制金融资本主义的过度行为。而且该公司的学术地位对其利润的影响可能比以前要小。所有企业顾问都必须担心向谁提供建议，权衡潜在客户的数量和他们的财力。但在美国老板们最艰难的时刻，瓦赫特尔选择了正确的选择。事实证明，这是非常有利可图的。律师通常按小时计费。 Wachtell 经常根据参与的价值收费，要求客户在成功的情况下支付一定费用，这种模式类似于投资银行家敲诈客户的方式。

并不是每个人都高兴。 X（该公司以前称为 Twitter）于 7 月起诉 Wachtell。在埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk) 试图退出价值 440 亿美元的将社交媒体平台私有化的协议后，瓦赫特尔 (Wachtell) 代表 Twitter 行事。去年 10 月，马斯克屈服了，Wachtell 因其麻烦而获得了 9000 万美元的报酬，X 现在认为这笔费用不合理。保守的假设是，Twitter 的价值在 4 月到 10 月之间下跌了 17%，与科技股纳斯达克指数一致，Twitter 的股东通过保留 Wachtell 得到了一笔很棒的交易：如果马斯克先生的话，他们的股票总价值可能会减少约 70 亿美元设法摆脱交易。在这种情况下，哪怕是轻微的倾斜，对于国王和朝臣来说都具有巨大的价值。

其他企业顾问可以从这一成功中学到什么？ Wachtell 运营模式的某些要素仅适用于提供类似高价值服务的小公司。当统一补偿员工时，搭便车的问题在大企业中变得难以忍受。一般来说，时光倒流，按照不成文的君子协议来经营公司并不是明智之举（精品投资银行 Centerview 最近因涉嫌欠其一位前合伙人的利润而在法庭上打官司）。

真正的教训是，坚持不懈地专注于自己的优势并拒绝成长可以得到回报。随着银行家、律师和顾问的生活和生计发生根本性变化已经迫在眉睫，还有其他一些变化。

电脑说也许

随着计算技术的最新进步，本应由办公软件颠覆的任务——20 多岁的人调整样板估值倍数直到凌晨——应该变得更加容易和便宜。进展可能很缓慢，但老板们应该越来越期望将商品化的任务外包出去。这可能意味着昂贵的初级员工的计费时间会减少。与此同时，在紧张局势下尖锐的呼吁仍然很有价值：合同中的语言和董事会中的自我意识的现实意味着公司冲突永远不会短缺。作为回应，预计幸存的公司将采用 Wachtell 采用的合伙人轻模式，取代他们的小兵大军，并在此过程中提高利润。 ■

; Wed, 02 Aug 2023 18:35:05 GMT /内容/msqk48hrnubh10hs6lagu4h9vko5jep3 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/08/02/meet-americas-most-profitable-law-firm Can big tech keep getting bigger in the age of AI?

有什么可以阻止大型科技公司吗？在经历了 2022 年封锁后的动荡之后，美国的数字巨头已经卷土重来。继第一季度表现出色后，上周 Alphabet、Meta 和微软都报告了第二季度的强劲业绩。 1 月至 6 月期间，三者合计实现营业利润 1060 亿美元，比去年同期增加 90 亿美元。

不要指望监管机构阻止他们的前进。上个月，一家法院驳回了美国反垄断机构阻止微软收购游戏开发商动视暴雪的努力。市场已经摆脱了其他控制科技巨头的断断续续的努力，例如欧盟针对数字市场的新规则。

更重要的是，投资者期望科技巨头凭借深厚的技术洞察力和雄厚的财力，攫取人工智能（ AI ）的战利品。 Alphabet、亚马逊和 Meta 的股价都在回升至 2021 年的峰值。微软和苹果（与亚马逊一起于 8 月 3 日公布最新季度财报）的股价比以往任何时候都高。

然而，数字巨头仍然必须考虑最强大的力量：算术。大型科技公司增长的主要限制是其自身的规模。未来几年，这将是大型科技公司面临的真正挑战。

Alphabet、亚马逊、苹果、Meta 和微软称霸美国商业。这五家公司在标准普尔500 股票市场指数中占据主导地位，合计占其销售额的 9%、净利润的 16% 和市值的 22%。去年，它们的资本支出达 3600 亿美元，占美国商业投资总额的十分之一以上。

但正是它们的持续增长使它们在资本主义历史上独一无二。当埃克森美孚和通用电气在20世纪90年代和2000年代是美国公司的巨头时，他们的收入平均每年增长5-6%，净利润每年平均增长5-10%左右。十多年来，科技巨头的增长率分别为 16% 和 13%。

为了维持 28% 的长期平均销售额增长，Alphabet 需要在 2024 年增加 860 亿美元的营收，超过去年标普500 指数中 461 家规模最小的公司中任何一家的营收，并在 2025 年再增加 1110 亿美元。如此，年复一年，筋疲力尽。为了保持利润以历史速度增长，明年苹果和 Alphabet 必须额外赚取 250 亿美元，或者大约相当于 Meta 的净利润； Meta 必须获得 Verizon 的认可。然后他们需要再次打破自己的记录。

从长远来看，维持这些平均水平肯定要求过高。事实上，近来的增长已经不那么强劲了。但这些公司的老板和投资者不太可能满足于经济放缓。如果是这样，他们将需要关注公司发展的三种主要方式。这些对大型科技公司有用吗？

一是追求利润，瘦身。削减成本、缩减项目规模和剥离非核心部门是寻求缓冲利润的传统企业的首选策略。大型科技公司可能非常规，但它也看到了节食的必要性。苹果是今年五巨头中唯一一家没有宣布裁员的公司；其他公司总共解雇了 70,000 多名工人。尽管如此，这家 iPhone 制造商还是推迟了一些新设备的发布。 Alphabet 已经放弃了一些由谷歌搜索资助的烧钱登月计划。亚马逊已经放弃了一些实体店。

公司的第二条增长之路是全力发展其核心业务。微软增强型人工智能搜索引擎 Bing 在今年早些时候作为潜在的 Google 杀手而受到了所有人的关注。事实上，Bing 仍然是搜索领域的失败者（老生常谈的是，其搜索次数最多的词是“Google”）。但类似GPT的聊天功能正在以不那么大张旗鼓的方式进入微软的企业产品中。上个月，该公司表示将向 Office 365 用户提供生成式人工智能工具，每月额外支付 30 美元。谷歌和 Meta 正在为其广告客户投资人工智能服务。

最雄心勃勃的增长战略是寻求新市场。这五家公司都在互相侵犯对方的地盘。自 2015 年以来，他们在重叠地区的销售份额翻了一番，达到 40%。 Alphabet 在云计算领域正在向亚马逊和微软发起挑战。亚马逊和微软正在尝试涉足广告领域。 6 月，苹果推出了一款虚拟现实耳机来与 Meta 竞争，而 Meta 迄今为止几乎占据了这个市场。这五个国家还在评估最后未受干扰的市场——包括金融、医疗保健和公共采购——这些市场足够大，足以对其庞大的收入产生显着的影响。或者，像微软一样，他们可能会尝试购买增长——以 690 亿美元收购动视暴雪将带来约 80 亿美元的年销售额。

这些方法都不是万无一失的。瘦身只能提高一两年的利润，而且是以牺牲未来收入为代价的。大型科技公司的主要市场——无论是 iPhone、数字广告还是商业软件——不再可靠地以 20% 或更高的速度增长。相互竞争带来了新的收入，但压缩了利润。不受干扰的市场往往不受干扰是有充分理由的：它们受到从华尔街银行到五角大楼承包商等现有企业的严格监管和控制。即使是现金充裕的大型科技公司也无法长期挥霍 690 亿美元来获得额外的数十亿美元收入。

从天而降

也许有一天，计算会吞噬世界。如果是这样，大型科技公司最终可以利用其人工智能实力从各行各业的现有企业手中夺取业务。从今天到最终，每家公司选择的战略组合将充分说明它如何看待自己。对削减成本的偏好标志着成熟，但也标志着缺乏信心。对扩张的渴望会暗示着自信——或者可能是傲慢。股东和高管应该为一段不确定的时期做好准备，因为旧的租金已经消失，而新的租金尚未找到。其他人都将享受大型科技公司梦想保持领先地位的丰富产品。 ■

世界上最不宜居的城市开始改善

中东和非洲仍处于经济学人智库指数的底部。但他们的分数却在上升

2 月 19 日，当南极洲附近海冰覆盖的面积降至 1.8m km 2 （800,000 平方英里）时——这是自 1978 年获得卫星数据以来的最小范围——很少有气候学家感到惊讶。在全球变暖的背景下，这样的记录经常会被打破，就像 2017 年和 2022 年的同一时间一样。3 月份，南极洲的冰盖开始以每天 70,000 公里2的速度反弹，接近历史平均水平。

然而，4月至6月期间，冰层并没有按预期恢复，增长率比正常水平低15%左右。七月初，它的边缘转向南边，在它本应迅速前进的时候却后退了。到 7 月 6 日，南极海冰覆盖面积仅为 12m km 2 ，大致相当于巴西和印度的总和。与1981-2010年的平均面积相比，其面积缩小了284万平方公里，与阿根廷或哈萨克斯坦的差距一样大。

与长期模式相比，这种突然下降看起来更加极端。与北极不同的是，近几十年来，北极海冰的最大范围逐渐缩小​​，最小海冰范围急剧下降，而南极洲的冰盖范围在过去半个世纪中相对稳定。 1976年至2014年间，该地区仲冬海冰的平均覆盖面积实际上略有增长。多种因素导致了地球两极之间冰盖趋势的历史差异，一极是被水包围的大陆，另一极是被陆地包围的海洋。但多年来，南极水域似乎是一片罕见的气候平静的海洋，现在该地区的海冰图看起来就像众所周知的汹涌澎湃的南大洋一样狂风暴雨。

现在判断南极海域异常的不结冰是否代表临时因素的不寻常融合还为时过早。气候变化驱动的新常态；或介于两者之间的东西。主要的短期解释之一是异常的风浪模式。整个六月和七月，从别林斯高晋海吹向南极的阵风阻止了南极半岛附近形成冰。印度洋风暴产生的天气系统——由厄尔尼诺南方涛动和南方环状模这两种定期大气波动的变化引起——也可能在东南极洲开始形成海冰时破裂。

温暖的海水也可能发挥了作用。最近的研究表明，自2016年以来，南大洋平均气温上升导致南极海冰缩小。这种模式可能源于整体大气变暖，但也可能是由于海洋深部和浅部之间正常热传递循环的变化造成的。

然而，即使冰盖最终恢复到最近的正常水平，其今年的消失行为也符合科学家的长期预期。根据目前对全球气温的预测，气候模型预测，南极海冰的范围将在本世纪下半叶缩小。尽管漂浮海冰的消失不会直接影响海平面，但它可能会加速陆地冰川的消失。

海冰有助于保持南极洲边缘凉爽。白冰反射阳光，减少海洋吸收的能量，从而降低空气和水温。此外，南极洲周围的海冰环固定住了该大陆的沿海冰架，反过来又对其冰川和冰盖起到了同样的作用。如果这些冰架崩塌（就像 2022 年南极洲东部的康格冰架那样），大陆冰就会迅速流入海洋。仅南极西部冰盖所含的水量就足以使全球海平面上升 3.3 米（11 英尺）。 ■

; Wed, 02 Aug 2023 17:43:29 GMT /内容/cmrfm7dsuro1eodo1vmsicbbvpqmfg9m https://www.economist.com/graphic-detail/2023/08/02/the-rapid-loss-of-antarctic-sea-ice-brings-grim-scenarios-into-view The debate over selling dinosaurs

自然历史拍卖正在兴起，为私人化石猎人带来了数百万美元的收入，但古代骨骼的商业化令一些古生物学家感到担忧。他们认为，私人出售的标本对科学来说是一种迷失。还有人说，通过抑制黑市并鼓励更多爱好者寻找稀有发现，化石拍卖可以提高对古代爬行动物的科学认识。

《经济学人》的迪伦·巴里 (Dylan Barry) 与古生物学家保罗·巴雷特 (Paul Barrett) 一起探索伦敦自然历史博物馆的化石收藏。迪伦还与商业化石勘探者“恐龙牛仔”克莱顿·菲普斯谈论了他对“恐龙决斗”的发现以及牧场主如何从寻找恐龙骨骼中受益。此外，苏富比拍卖行副总裁兼自然历史部主管卡桑德拉·哈顿认为，拍卖师和古生物学家应该将彼此视为站在同一边。肯尼思·库基尔主持。时长：43分钟

; Wed, 02 Aug 2023 17:23:22 GMT /内容/2idbunquehu9v70p0pn19dtqeuh1japd https://www.economist.com/podcasts/2023/08/02/the-debate-over- sell-dinosaurs An ancient whale-like animal may be the biggest to have ever lived

恐龙如此受小学生欢迎的原因之一是它们中的许多都非常大。霸王龙是一种肉食动物，身长可达 12 米，大约是网球场长度的一半，据信体重可达 7 吨。一些食草恐龙的体型更大：2014 年发现的巴塔哥泰坦巨龙 (Patagotitan mayorum)长 37m，重可能达 69 吨。

但真正的巨人并不生活在陆地上，陆地上的重力限制了动物的生长重量。它们生活在海里，巨大的身体可以由水支撑。这种有史以来最大的动物至今仍在游动。蓝鲸（ Balaenoptera musculus）的体重经常超过 100 吨。一些估计估计个体的体重为 190 吨。

但现在，蓝鲸似乎有了挑战者。 8 月 2 日，在《自然》杂志上发表的一篇论文中，比萨大学古生物学家乔瓦尼·比安努奇 (Giovanni Bianucci) 和他的同事描述了巨型秘鲁巨蜥 ( Perucetus colossus) ，这是一种已灭绝的海洋哺乳动物，大约 4000 万年前曾在海洋浅滩游过。它的重量可能高达 340 吨，是迄今为止存在的最大的动物。

或者至少，这是最高估计。比安努奇博士和他的团队在秘鲁南部干旱沙漠伊卡谷工作，只找到了一具不完整的骨骼，由 13 块椎骨和 4 根肋骨组成。准确计算出这些骨头上曾经附着了多少肉并不容易。利用现有海洋哺乳动物的骨骼与身体质量比，研究人员得出了 85 吨的较低估计值，以及 180 吨的中心数字。

目前还不清楚这种动物为何如此之大。可以肯定的是，规模有它的优势。温度控制就是其中之一。哺乳动物必须将体温保持在一个严格的范围内。当它们变大时，它们的表面积增长得比体积增长得慢。这意味着体型较大的生物在相对寒冷的海洋中更容易保持温暖。

但也有缺点。最明显的是，身体越大，胃口越大，越难满足。生物学家认为，鲸鱼在大约 500 万年前才达到了现代的比例，当时气候变化为它们巨大的身体提供了丰富的摄食条件。由于P. colossus在这些变化之前已经生活了数百万年，因此必须有其他原因来解释它的重要性。

弄清楚一种已灭绝的动物是如何生活的，比确定它有多大还要困难。但有线索。 P. colossus骨骼的一个显着特征是其密度。研究人员发现的所有骨头都异常厚重。有些缺乏髓腔，这是大多数哺乳动物骨骼中间发现的一个中空、充满骨髓的部分。如今，抹香鲸等深潜海洋哺乳动物的骨骼往往相对较轻，它们可以潜到 1000 米以上。生活在较浅水域的动物，例如海牛，它们的骨头很致密。因此，研究人员认为P. colossus同样是相对肥沃的沿海浅滩的生物。

由于没有下巴或任何牙齿可供研究，它到底吃什么还不清楚。一种理论认为它是一种草食动物，通过咀嚼大量的海草和海藻来生存。它可能是像现代须鲸一样的滤食动物，从水中滤出小生物。研究人员推测，它甚至可能是一种食腐动物，以其他动物的尸体为生。最终的答案以及对记录簿的更新可能必须等到更完整的骨架被发现。 ■

当路易斯·伊纳西奥·卢拉·达席尔瓦去年当选巴西总统时，投资者感到震惊。许多人担心他的工人党前任政府会再次出现财政挥霍的现象，该政府于 2016 年陷入严重衰退。然而，在他上任六个月后，市场对卢拉政府的态度正在升温。最近对 94 名巴西基金经理和分析师进行的一项民意调查显示，只有 44% 的人对政府持负面看法，低于 3 月份的 90%。 7月26日，评级机构惠誉自2018年下调巴西长期外币债务评级以来首次上调巴西长期外币债务评级。

巴西财富的改善在一定程度上是卢拉无法控制的事情的结果。俄罗斯入侵乌克兰使世界上两个最大的粮食生产国（俄罗斯和乌克兰）的出口面临风险。中国取消了疫情限制，推高了食品需求。这两个因素都增加了巴西谷物的需求。仅大豆出口就可以占今年经济增长的五分之一。这使得该国的贸易顺差不断增加，而该国的贸易顺差已经很大了（见图1）。

同样，美国和中国之间日益紧张的关系，以及美国明年可能降息的可能性，正促使许多投资者将目光投向新兴市场。去年巴西接收了超过 910 亿美元的外国直接投资 ( FDI )，使其成为世界第五大投资目的地。这是 2021 年数字的两倍。尽管 2022 年全球FDI流入量比 2021 年下降了 12%，但这一增长还是发生了。“人们现在肯定以过去十年从未有过的方式看待巴西， ”华盛顿国际金融研究所的罗宾·布鲁克斯说。

巴西央行的独立性也有帮助。卢拉经常对其总统罗伯托·坎波斯·内托进行讽刺。卢拉指责内托先生将利率维持在世界最高水平的13.75%，从而抑制了经济增长。但该银行的政策似乎已收到成效。年通胀率从去年 4 月的 12% 降至如今的 3.2%（尽管预计年底将在 5% 左右）。预计该银行本周将降低利率。有助于保持低通胀的因素之一是雷亚尔兑美元升值。

令人陶醉的组合

卢拉政府的多项政策也提振了投资者的士气。许多经济学家将大部分乐观情绪归功于财政部长费尔南多·哈达德（上图为卢拉）。他是两项重大改革的幕后推手，这两项改革可能会让巴西的基础更加稳定。 7月7日，下议院通过了一项宪法修正案，以推动酝酿了三十年的税收改革。今年晚些时候，国会将批准新的财政框架以稳定公共财政。

首先考虑税制改革。这是非常必要的：目前联邦政府、所有 27 个州和 5,000 多个市都制定了自己的税收。 2019 年，世界银行估计，企业每年需要花费 1,500 小时来遵守巴西税法，而全球平均水平为 233 小时。税收改革将把五种商品和服务税合并为两种增值税，一种是联邦税，一种是地方税。预计将于今年晚些时候获得批准。内托先生表示，在实施的第一年内， GDP可能增长 1.5%。

该财政框架将以灵活的规则取代自 2016 年以来一直被打破的严格支出上限。新规定将联邦政府基本支出增幅限制为上一年收入增长的70%，旨在明年实现基本预算平衡（即扣除利息成本），并从2025年起实现基本盈余。如果政府没有达到目标，支出增长将收紧至仅上一年收入增长的50%，并且政府将不允许提高公职人员的工资等限制。巴西央行表示，随着时间的推移，这应该会稳定巴西的公共债务总额，目前该债务占GDP的 74%。 （央行不包括其自身持有的债务。根据国际货币基金组织的衡量标准，巴西的公共债务总额约为GDP的 90%。）

即使那些持怀疑态度的人也认为债务最终会得到控制。投资公司沃伦 (Warren) 的费利佩·萨尔托 (Felipe Salto) 表示，今年早些时候，“我们的客户中存在很多悲观情绪”。现在许多人看到了“未来几年的财富”。

投资者还在关注巴西生产清洁能源的潜力，以及卢拉使该国成为绿色强国的雄心。本月，政府将推出一揽子约 100 项环境举措，其中包括一项建立碳排放监管市场的法律和一项促进绿色产业发展的法律。政府估计该计划将需要数千亿美元，其中大部分是私人投资。经过欧盟和南方共同市场（一个由巴西、阿根廷、巴拉圭和乌拉圭组成的贸易集团）二十多年的谈判后，自由贸易协定也可能很快签署（尽管巴西和欧盟的保护主义本能尚未实现）破坏这个）。

但乐观情绪应该有所缓和。首先，税收改革和财政框架的成功并不能得到保证。税收改革的细节尚未敲定。这意味着目前尚不清楚新的增值税税率是多少，也不清楚有多少行业将享受税率降低或豁免。农业企业游说团体一直在推动该规则的措辞纳入食品免税，其中可能包括大量产品。

为政府改革提供咨询的顾问爱德华多·弗勒里 (Eduardo Fleury) 表示，其他行业获得特殊待遇的越多，总体标准税率就会越高。税负上升幅度最大的服务业面临的阻力最大。 “我们需要的是税收改革，而不是税收革命，”全国商业、服务和旅游联合会的吉列尔姆·梅尔塞斯 (Guilherme Mercês) 表示。

征税时间

也不确定政府的财政状况是否会井然有序。预算部长西蒙·特贝特 (Simone Tebet) 表示，政府希望明年通过额外增加 260 亿美元收入（相当于GDP的 1.1% 左右）来实现基本平衡，而不是削减支出或专注于增长。其中大部分将来自打击逃税、改革所得税和对在线博彩征税。国会最近还投票决定恢复行政部门解决税务上诉案件陷入僵局的判决的能力。 Tebet 女士估计，2020 年失去的这项权利每年未征收的税款价值为 80 亿美元。

然而，巴西独立财政研究所 ( IFI ) 的维尔玛·平托 (Vilma Pinto) 表示，政府不太可能实现其目标。由于追回逃税损失的资金非常困难，而且国会批准新税种也需要时间， IFI估计政府明年只能征收 180 亿美元。特贝特女士自信地宣称，如果明年不能实现预算平衡，政府将削减支出。 “本届政府意识到，没有财政责任就不可能有社会福利，”她说。 “如果没有财政责任，通货膨胀将会爆发，这是所有税收中最不正当的。”

特贝特女士是政府高层的温和派。但她的老板不太热衷于正统观念。卢拉在上任的头 100 天内增加了社会支出，每年增加 240 亿美元。他最近还推出了一项补贴，为汽车、卡车和公共汽车制造商提供税收减免。这是一辆价值 3 亿美元的一次性廉价汽车，对中产阶级来说是一种安抚。 7 月 12 日，他提议对白色家电采取同样的做法。

历史告诫人们不要过度热情。巴西拥有巨大的潜力，但一直在承受压力。在经历了大宗商品繁荣时期的十年增长之后，实际GDP在 2014 年至 2019 年间平均每年收缩 0.3%。农业以外的生产力在过去 30 年里没有增长（见图 2）。尽管自 2021 年疫情结束以来经济增长有所反弹，但仍远远落后于中国或印度等国家。全球背景和哈达德先生的实力现在正在提振投资者的乐观情绪。但要扭转巴西的长期趋势，就需要持续的良好政策。 ■

; Wed, 02 Aug 2023 15:18:37 GMT /内容/unln3reikckam42eiom194hntkjmu1d3 https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2023/08/02/investors-are-increasingly-optimistic-about-brazils-economy Ukrainian soldiers describe their experiences battling Russia

当他的手下进攻时，他们以为自己已经做好了一切准备。他们错了。 “It was a black cloud,” says a platoon commander with the callsign Pole, earned after he worked in Warsaw for a decade before coming home to fight. “I don't know if the beehives were destroyed in fighting or if the Russians opened them,” he says, but for a surreal moment thousands of enraged bees forced the men of the 128th Mountain Assault Brigade to run for it, while the Russians ran the other way, covering their retreat with rocket-propelled grenades.

Sheltering beneath trees from the sun and from Russian drones, Pole and dozens of his comrades are waiting to be transported to trenches dug alongside fields resplendent with sunflowers in full bloom. From 10km away the boom of Ukrainian artillery can be heard. Beyond the cannon Ukrainian forces are battling the Russians in a bloody struggle for every metre in their attempt to punch a way through their defences on the southern Zaporizhia front.

These men could get the order to join the fray at any moment, says the company's commander, known as Karp. For now, they are training. An infantry fighting vehicle arrives, 15 men clamber on and in a cloud of choking fumes it lurches off, transporting them to the trenches. As it lumbers through the countryside south of the road to Orikhiv, bright yellow birds flit across its path.

Most of the men are freshly called up. The nearby village of Piatykhatky was liberated by the brigade in mid-June, but the casualty rate of the operation was so high that new recruits are being readied to make up its depleted numbers. A soldier who gives his callsign as Looter says that most of the Piatykhatky casualties were wounded rather than killed. But, he adds, “I took our commander's head from his tank.” It can be assumed that similar exercises are taking place across these endless southern fields, as men are prepared to replace those lost in the counter-offensive, which began on June 4th.

Ukraine's push south is proceeding painfully slowly. Russian troops have prepared formidable defences which the Ukrainians are finding hard to breach. These include drones transmitting live pictures back to their operators, minefields and lingering munitions. They have hugely increased the challenges that Ukraine's soldiers are facing compared with last year.

“The worst are tripwires,” says Pole. “which you cannot see at night, and set off a whole string of connected mines.” Combat medics who ask not to be named say that most casualties they evacuate have been injured by mines.

Arriving at the trench, the men leap off their fighting vehicle and practise “cleaning” the area of Russians. One might assume that they would only ever see a live Russian from a distance, or on a screen via pictures transmitted from a drone. Karp cautions that that is not the case. “I tell them that you can meet an enemy at even two or three metres. It happened to me. I met a Russian officer at four metres. I killed him right off.”

With a prominent beard and hair done in wartime-fashionable Cossack style, with shaved sides and a topknot, Karp is a grizzled veteran who took shrapnel to his head and neck during the Kherson offensive last October. He is only 28, but has been in the army since 2014. What annoys him more than anything are the back-seat drivers of the war. One soldier complains: “Everyone is saying 'Go, go, go' but these sofa-experts don't understand the war's reality.” Karp adds: “They are telling us how to fight and our answer is 'Come and join our unit and then tell us what to do, and let's see how much of a hero you are then!'”

To the north of these fields lies the main road running from the city of Zaporizhia to the shattered town of Orikhiv. This is the jumping-off point for one of the counter-offensive's main thrusts. Smoke can be seen rising from a wrecked petrol station in the distance, and the sound of artillery punctures the summer silence of the fields.

A constant stream of troops moves back and forth. German-made Leopard tanks rumble by. With a deep, roaring grumble a tracked steel behemoth passes, a de-miner of the type Ukrainian forces are desperately short of. Its crew have stacked their rolled-up mattresses, boxes and bags of kit on top.

In shops along the dusty road soldiers buy provisions. Many travel and fight as tight-knit groups of comrades who have acquired sturdy 4x4s, often decorated with stickers such as a traffic sign of a crossed-out Putin or a pig in Russian colours. A unit that operates a Grad rocket launcher stops to buy. They complain that they have been supplied with Pakistani rockets, some of which are duds and all of which are far less precise than their long-exhausted stock of Ukrainian ones.

In the village of Preobrazhenka, just before Orikhiv, Ruslan, a civilian, says that the counter-offensive has pushed the Russians back some 5km, meaning less artillery shelling. There are no longer any children here, he says, but there are old people who need help.

The village is still being bombed, he says, pointing to a pile of rubble that was once a building. The bombs are launched by aeroplanes above occupied Tokmak, 35km farther south and one of the main targets of the counter-offensive. Ruslan grumbles that the village would be safe if the West had already delivered the F-16 fighter jets that Ukraine wants. People here are tired but the mood is still positive, he says. “We are waiting for victory,” he says, a condition that will be satisfied “when those motherfuckers are killed.” ■

null; Wed, 02 Aug 2023 12:21:43 GMT /content/m6pmc2n8156onnokelubqkojb67jiesu https://www.economist.com/obituary/2023/08/02/sunray-kelley-wanted-to-build-in-rhythm-with-nature-his-teacher What is AMOC, the Atlantic current that distributes heat around the world?

A SK A CLIMATE scientist about possible “tipping points” and you are likely to hear about AMOC . The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation is a stream of water which, as it flows from the southern to the northern (hence “meridional”) part of the Atlantic, grows cooler and saltier. Eventually it sinks to the ocean floor, 3km down, and flows back (hence “overturning”) across the abyssal plain. Mounting evidence suggests that the system that helps distribute heat around the world is weakening. Why do scientists find this so worrying?

AMOC is something of a poster child for tipping points, which are notional thresholds beyond which systems that have been responding gradually and incrementally to global warming undergo sudden and dramatic changes. One reason for this is its sheer power and the scope of its influence. The rate at which it transfers heat towards the pole—about one petawatt, or 1,000 terawatts, roughly 60 times the rate at which humans produce energy by burning fossil fuels in factories, furnaces, power stations, cars, aircraft and everything else—accounts for about a quarter of all the northward flow of heat from the tropics. At least half of the water that gets into the ocean depths does so in the North Atlantic.

Another reason is that its tipping-point nature is not open to question. Theory, modelling and reconstructions of prehistoric climate all support the idea that AMOC is “bistable”. Rather than just gradually getting stronger or weaker, it can go suddenly from “on” to “off” if pushed too far, and does so in a way that makes it very hard to flip it back on again. It was one of the first such instabilities clearly demonstrated in the climate system. And on top of all that there has long been good reason to think that global warming may be pushing that switch. On July 25th a paper published in Nature Communications suggested that the change of state could come about by the middle of this century.

The overturning circulation is often confused with the Gulf Stream, which runs across the Atlantic in the same direction, but there is a crucial difference. The Gulf Stream is pushed along by winds which will persist whatever the climate. The waters of AMOC are drawn forward by the sinking of those ahead of them, as if on a conveyor-belt. If the near-surface part of the circulation stops getting salty (and thus dense) enough to sink, the circulation stops, and warm water stays where it is. The amount of heat moving north falls by more than half.

That would have dire effects. Northern Europe would get both colder—bringing worse winters, more powerful storms inland and shorter growing seasons—and drier, making summers more prone to drought. The impact on agriculture would be far greater than that caused by warming alone, hitting poorer countries hardest. By slowing the transfer of heat to the north, such a state would push the “intertropical convergence zone”—the tropical belt where the weather systems of the two hemispheres meet—towards the south. This could lead to a drying out of the southern edge of the Sahara, and a spectacular desiccation of Central and northern South America, as well as other impacts around the globe.

Wallace Broecker, an American oceanographer whose work in the 1980s first demonstrated the on-off nature of AMOC , saw it as a powerful cautionary tale for how suddenly climate change could come. “The climate is an angry beast,” he used to say, “and we are poking it with a sharp stick.”

The stick in question is a freshening of the water in the North Atlantic caused by increased rainfall and melting ice, both expected results of warming caused by greenhouse gases. The climate models used by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ( IPCC ) show this leading to a weakening of the circulation over this century, an outcome the panel sees as “very likely” (with a probability above 90%). But they do not show it weakening enough to cross the tipping point and shut itself down.

The lack of a shutdown in the models was one of the reasons that, up until the 2010s, the IPCC tended to be pretty sanguine about the risks. In 2019 it said a shutdown this century was “very unlikely” in 2019. Its most recent assessment, published in 2021, saw the panel recognise that new data and new modelling made it harder to say anything that certain. In some ways that felt almost like good news: it lowered its level of confidence in the idea that measurements made since the 19th century showed a slowdown to already be under way. In other ways it was alarming. This time the conclusion that there would be no shutdown this century was offered with only “medium” confidence. One factor in that reassessment was an acceptance that climate models are systematically biased towards stability in this particular respect. Another was that they did not take specific account of the effects of melting Greenland ice.

In light of this uncertainty, some scientists are seeking out early warnings of a shutdown. The paper that Peter and Susanne Ditlevsen, both at the University of Copenhagen, published in Nature Communications in July was such an attempt, using statistics to spot subtle signs of an approaching tipping point. Direct measurements of the strength of AMOC go back only as far as the deployment of the sensor system called RAPID in 2004. So instead the researchers studied a “fingerprint” of the circulation based on surface temperatures in a particular patch of the North Atlantic since the 1870s. Their statistical analysis suggested a 95% chance of a shutdown in the window from 2025 to 2095.

Though the authors tried to limit the number of assumptions they made, some could still prove erroneous. One such is that AMOC ’s potential tipping point would lead to its total collapse; it might instead shift into some other mode, perhaps one where the location of the sinking moves elsewhere but the flow continues. In that sense AMOC is similar to other systems where tipping points have been diagnosed, such as the conversion of the Amazon into savannah or the collapse of the West Antarctic ice sheet. All such angry beasts need further study to better characterise their behaviour. But no one should expect those studies to be conclusive—or expect any guarantee of calm until the poking with sharp sticks subsides. ■

; Wed, 02 Aug 2023 10:42:32 GMT /content/1o3168qgmf1hldoom9179joqndtdjnsq https://www.economist.com/podcasts/2023/08/02/donald-trump-has-been-indicted-again-but-he-has-more-republican-support-than-ever Donald Trump is facing his gravest charges yet

E ight weeks ago, when charges were unveiled related to his mishandling of classified documents , Donald Trump became the first former American president ever to face a federal indictment . On August 1st he became the first to battle two sets of federal charges at the same time. The Department of Justice ( D o J ) accused the former president of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election—a race he still insists he won—in violation of three federal laws. The new charges are the gravest to date against Mr Trump, and will inject yet more jeopardy into the 2024 presidential race.

As in June, it was the defendant who broke the news. On July 18th, in a vituperative social-media post, Mr Trump acknowledged that he had received a letter from the D o J naming him as a target. When the indictment arrived on August 1st he likened the department's actions to those of “Nazi Germany in the 1930s”.

The new charges follow a lengthy process. A 17-month investigation by a congressional committee advised the D o J to bring criminal charges. In December Jack Smith, who was appointed special counsel by Merrick Garland, the attorney-general, took up that mantle in what became an eight-month investigation of his own. The probe culminated in Mr Smith's decision to charge Mr Trump with criminal liability for his efforts to remain in the White House despite losing the election in 2020.

Notably, Mr Trump's speech on January 6th 2021, in which he urged his supporters to march to the Capitol and “fight like hell”, was not central to the charges. No direct link between Mr Trump's words and the attack on the Capitol is alleged in the 45-page charging document. In fact, Mr Smith states that Mr Trump had a First Amendment right to express his views on the election, and “even to claim, falsely”, that election fraud was responsible for his defeat.

Rather than try to tie Mr Trump's words to the rioters' actions in an incitement charge, Mr Smith meticulously outlines how his efforts in the days and weeks after the election amounted to a conspiracy to defraud America, obstruct Congress's official proceeding certifying the election, and deprive Americans of their civil rights by wiping away their votes for Joe Biden. Mr Trump's claims of widespread election fraud “were false”, the document reads, and Mr Trump “knew that they were false”.

As evidence that Mr Trump was aware that his loss was legitimate, the document lists a host of officials and advisers who told him the truth: that “various allegations of fraud were unsupported”. Mike Pence, the vice-president, is one. Others include senior officials in the D o J , the director of national intelligence, senior campaign staffers, allies in state legislatures, and dozens of state and federal judges. People Mr Trump depended on for “candid advice on important matters” told him bluntly that his claims of substantial fraud were false.

The former president solicited a lot of help in trying to upend his electoral loss, the document asserts. Mr Smith refers—not by name but by their respective roles in the scheme—to six co-conspirators, including a quintet of lawyers. He did not announce charges against any of them. But he hinted that they should not rest easy. “Our investigation of other individuals continues,” Mr Smith said at a press conference, adding that the D o J was “committed to ensuring accountability for those criminally responsible” for the events of January 6th 2021.

The calendar may have figured prominently in the decision to limit the case to Mr Trump for now. Mr Smith emphasised his desire for “a speedy trial”—presumably one that might be held before the November 2024 election. A half-dozen extra defendants would almost certainly have put that goal out of reach.

Yet much could depend on the outcome of that vote. Even with charges limited to a single defendant and a quick schedule set by the judge, Tanya Chutkan, time will be on Mr Trump's side if he wins the election. Sitting presidents are immune from criminal prosecution, meaning all Mr Trump's pending trials and appeals—the two federal indictments, as well as state charges related to hush-money payments in New York (the Stormy Daniels case), and possible election-fraud charges in Georgia—would be placed on hold. Final resolution of his legal troubles could be delayed until 2029 or beyond. On the other hand, should Mr Trump lose again, the cases will proceed as normal. Fifteen months out, polls suggest that he and Mr Biden are neck-and-neck. ■
